sub_topic: Probability of a certain event occurring in a given time period
message_1: A daycare center has 12 toddlers playing at a given time. On average, each toddler has a 5% chance of needing to use the restroom in the next 30 minutes. What is the probability that at least 2 toddlers will need to use the restroom in the next 30 minutes?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where P(X = k) is the probability of k successes (toddlers needing to use the restroom) in n trials (12 toddlers), C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time, p is the probability of success (5% or 0.05), and (1-p) is the probability of failure (95% or 0.95).

First, we will find the probability of 0 toddlers needing to use the restroom and 1 toddler needing to use the restroom. Then, we will subtract these probabilities from 1 to find the probability of at least 2 toddlers needing to use the restroom.

P(X = 0) = C(12, 0) * 0.05^0 * 0.95^12
P(X = 0) = 1 * 1 * 0.54036
P(X = 0) = 0.54036

P(X = 1) = C(12, 1) * 0.05^1 * 0.95^11
P(X = 1) = 12 * 0.05 * 0.56880
P(X = 1) = 0.34224

Now, we will find the probability of at least 2 toddlers needing to use the restroom:

P(X ≥ 2) = 1 - P(X = 0) - P(X = 1)
P(X ≥ 2) = 1 - 0.54036 - 0.34224
P(X ≥ 2) = 1 - 0.88260
P(X ≥ 2) = 0.11740

So, the probability that at least 2 toddlers will need to use the restroom in the next 30 minutes is approximately 11.74%.
